raw_text:
Japan economy slides to recession
 
 The Japanese economy has officially gone back into recession for the fourth time in a decade.
 
 Gross domestic product fell by 0.1% in the last three months of 2004. The fall reflects weak exports and a slowdown in consumer spending, and follows similar falls in GDP in the two previous quarters. The Tokyo stock market fell after the figures were announced, but rose again on a widespread perception that the economy will recover later this year. On Wednesday, the government revised growth figures from earlier in 2004 which, when taking into account performance in the most recent period, effectively tips Japan into recession.
 
 A previous estimate of 0.1% growth between July and September was downgraded to a 0.3% decline. A recession is commonly defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth, although the Japanese government takes other factors into account when judging the status of its economy.
 
 Figures released by the government's Cabinet Office showed that GDP, on an annualised basis, fell 0.5% in the last three months of 2004. However, politicians remain upbeat about prospects for an economic boost later in the year. "The economy has some soft patches but if you look at the bigger picture, it is in a recovery stage," said Economic and Fiscal Policy Minister Heizo Takenaka. Gross domestic product measures the overall value of goods and services produced in a country. "The economy must be assessed comprehensively and we cannot look at GDP alone," Mr Takenaka stressed.
 
 Ministers pointed to the fact that consumer spending had been depressed by one-off factors such as the unseasonably mild winter. Analysts said the figures were disappointing but argued that Japan's largest companies had been recording healthy profits and capital spending was on the rise. Japan's economy grew 2.6% overall last year - fuelled by a strong performance in the first few months - and is forecast to see growth of 2.1% in 2005. However, the economy's fragile recovery remains dependent on an upturn in consumer spending, a fall in the value of the yen and an improvement in global economies. "The results came in at the lower end of expectations but we shouldn't be too pessimistic about the current state and the outlook for the economy," said Naoki Iizuka, senior economist at the Dai-ichi Life Research Institute. Japan's economy has seen stretches of moderate growth over the past decade but has periodically slipped back into recession.
llama3.2:1b: Japan's economy fell by 0.1% in Q3 2004, according to revised figures released by the government's Cabinet Office.
The GDP fell 0.5% annually, with a 0.3% decline between July and September.
The economy is considered to be in recession due to weak exports and consumer spending.
Despite this, ministers remain optimistic about prospects for an economic recovery later in the year, citing factors such as healthy profits from large companies and rising capital spending.
Overall GDP growth is expected to slow down further to 2.1% in 2005.
llama3.2:3b: The Japanese economy has officially gone back into recession for the fourth time in a decade, with GDP falling by 0.1% in the last three months of 2004 due to weak exports and consumer spending.
The government revised earlier growth figures, effectively tipping Japan into recession, but officials remain optimistic about an economic boost later this year.
gemma2:2b: Japan's economy officially entered a recession for the fourth time in ten years, with GDP falling 0.1% in the last three months of 2004.
The decline was attributed to weak exports and consumer spending slowdown.
However, some economists and policymakers remain optimistic about an economic recovery later this year due to positive indicators such as company profits and rising capital spending.
The government believes a comprehensive assessment of the economy is necessary beyond GDP alone.
Overall, the economy saw growth in 2004 but its fragile recovery depends on consumer spending, yen depreciation, and global economic improvement.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Japan's economy has officially slid back into a fourth recession since 2004.
GDP fell by 0.1% in the last three months of 2004, reflecting weak exports and consumer spending.
The government revised its growth figures from earlier in 2004 to show an even worse situation, which analysts attribute to the rise in the value of the yen and a slowdown in global economies.
However, many economists remain optimistic about the current state of Japan's economy and the outlook for the future.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Japan's economy officially entered a third consecutive quarter in recession following a 0.1% decline in GDP for Q4 2004, marking four recessions since 2001.
Despite falling markets and expectations of an economic downturn, recent data suggests Japan may bounce back later this year, driven by capital spending and improved profit margins.
qwen2.5:3b: Japan's economy officially slid into a recession for the fourth time in ten years.
GDP fell by 0.1% in the last quarter of 2004, attributed to weak exports and reduced consumer spending.
The Tokyo stock market initially declined after the figures were released but recovered due to expectations of economic recovery later in the year.
Revised government data showed a decline of 0.3%, tipping Japan into recession.
Politicians remain optimistic about future growth despite short-term challenges.
GDP fell 0.5% annually, and analysts viewed the figures as disappointing but noted healthy corporate profits and increasing capital spending.
Overall, Japan's economy grew 2.6% last year and is forecast to grow by 2.1% in 2005.
The fragile recovery depends on improved consumer spending, a weakening yen, and stronger global economies.
opencoder:1.5b: The Japanese economy is experiencing an offbeat recovery from a 4-month period of decline in GDP and consumer spending, followed by another downward spiral in global economy growth.
Despite strong performance indicators, the economy's recovery struggles with slower increases in value and the volatile nature of international currencies.
smollm:1.7b: The Japanese economy has gone into a recession for the fourth time in a decade.
The GDP fell by 0.1% in the last three months of 2004, which is down from 0.3% growth seen earlier this year.
This decline reflects weak exports and a slowdown in consumer spending, which are key factors contributing to Japan's economic downturn.
The government revised its growth figures for the previous two quarters, effectively tipping Japan into recession.
The revised GDP figure of -0.3% is down from 0.5% growth seen earlier this year.
This decline is attributed to a combination of negative factors including a decline in exports and a slowdown in consumer spending.
On Wednesday, the government released its revised growth figures for the previous two quarters, which suggests that Japan's economy will recover later this year.
The revised GDP figure of -0.3% is down from 0.5% growth seen earlier this year.
This decline is attributed to a combination of negative factors including a decline in exports and a slowdown in consumer spending.

The Japanese government remains upbeat about prospects for an economic boost later in the year, citing the fact that Japan's largest companies have been recording healthy profits and capital spending is on the rise.
However, analysts argue that Japan's economy will need to recover from its current state before it can be considered a recession.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Japan's economy entered recession for the fourth time in a decade, driven by weak exports and consumer spending decline, though still expected to recover.
GDP fell 0.1% over three months of 2004, revised figures showing a 0.3% decline, which adjusted from previous estimates.
The stock market rose initially but then plummeted due to expectations of recovery later.
economists noted that GDP alone isn't sufficient for assessing the economy; other factors like consumer spending and global stability matter.
Key reasons: weak exports (cold winter impact), increased capital investment, yen depreciation, and Japan's strong global economic resilience.
Overall growth in 2004 was 2.6%, but they remain focused on improving consumer spending to gauge recovery.
outlook for 2005 is positive, expecting modest gains despite the initial slide.
Summary: Japan hasn't fully recovered but faces some signs of recovery, driven by weak consumer spending and improved global conditions.
They adjust outlook based on recent performance rather than just GDP numbers.
tinyllama:1.1b:
Concise summary:

Japan's economy officially went into a decline in August, following weak exports and a slowdown in consumer spendings as part of a broader slump.
The country is set to face continued economic contraction this year with growth forecasts pegged at 2.1% overall.

While consumers may have been depressed by one-off factors such as the mild winter, experts believe that Japan's largest companies have been recording healthy profits and capital spending is on the rise.
The country remains vulnerable to global economic downturns.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Japanese economy is in a recession for the fourth time in a decade, with Gross Domestic Product (GDP) falling by 0.1% in the last three months of 2004.
This decline is attributed to weaker exports and a slowdown in consumer spending.
Economists estimate that the economy will recover later this year but remain hopeful for future growth.
The Tokyo stock market fell after the figures were announced, signifying a negative outlook on the Japanese economy.
phi:2.7b: The Japanese economy has officially entered its fourth recession in a decade due to weak exports and consumer spending.
GDP fell by 0.1% in Q4, down from an earlier estimate of 0.3%, but is expected to recover later this year.
Despite the decline, economists remain optimistic about Japan's economic future as companies continue to record healthy profits and capital spending is on the rise.
However, the economy remains dependent on a pick-up in consumer spending, a fall in the value of the yen, and an improvement in global economies.
The country has seen periods of moderate growth in the past decade but has also experienced occasional recessions.
orca-mini:3b: The Japanese economy is in a recession for the fourth time in a decade after the government revised its growth figures and GDP fell 0.5% in the last three months of 2004.
This follows similar falls in GDP in the two previous quarters, and consumer spending has been depressed due to the unseasonably mild winter.

While analysts argue that Japan's largest companies have been recording healthy profits and capital spending is on the rise, the economy's fragile recovery remains dependent on an upturn in consumer spending, a fall in the value of the yen, and an improvement in global economies.

stablelm-zephyr:3b: The Japanese economy went into recession for the fourth time in a decade, with GDP falling by 0.1% in the last three months of 2004.
This was due to weak exports and a slowdown in consumer spending.
The Tokyo stock market fell but rose again after the figures were announced.
The government revised growth figures from earlier in 2004, which effectively tipped Japan into recession.
Analysts argued that although the figures were disappointing, Japan's largest companies had been recording healthy profits, and capital spending was on the rise.

Japan's economy grew 2.6% overall in 2003 and is forecast to see growth of 2.1% in 2005, but it remains dependent on an upturn in consumer spending, a fall in the value of the yen, and an improvement in global economies.
stablelm2:1.6b: Japan's economy goes into a fourth recession in a decade due to weak exports and slowdown in consumer spending.
GDP fell 0.1% in Q4 2018, following a previous decline in Q3.
This marks the first time Japan has gone into recession since 2012.
The government downgraded an initial estimate of 0.1% growth to a 0.3% decline after taking into account the most recent performance.
However, economists note that other factors may still contribute to economic recovery later in the year.
GDP declined by 0.5% annually over the last three months, according to figures released by the Cabinet Office.
The minister for Economic and Fiscal Policy stated that a more comprehensive assessment should be made of the economy's overall value before evaluating it solely through GDP growth.
Consumer spending was mentioned as having been depressed due to unseasonably mild winter conditions.
Despite these figures being disappointing, analysts argued that large Japanese companies were recording healthy profits, and capital spending was on the rise.
The economy grew 2.6% in 2017, largely driven by a strong start to the year, and is forecasted to see growth of 2.1% in 2019.
However, the country's fragile recovery remains dependent on an upturn in consumer spending, a drop in the value of the yen, and improvements in global economies.
Overall, Japan's economy has seen extended periods of moderate growth over the last decade but has been plagued by recessionary periods.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Japan's GDP contracted for the fourth time in a decade, marking its entry into recession.
In Q4 2004, GDP fell by 0.1%, primarily due to weak exports and decreased consumer spending following an unusually mild winter.
The government later revised previous growth estimates from 0.1% between July-September to a 0.3% decline.
Despite these figures, Minister Heizo Takenaka remained optimistic about the economy's recovery in the latter part of 2004 and projected 2.1% growth for 2005.
Analysts noted that while consumer spending had been affected, large corporations were still reporting robust profits and capital expenditures were rising.
Japan's overall GDP grew 2.6% in 2003 but is forecasted to reach 2.1% in 2005.
The economy's recovery hinges on increased consumer spending, a weaker yen, and global economic improvement.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Japan's economy has entered recession for the fourth time in a decade, with GDP falling 0.1% in the last quarter of 2004, following declines in the previous two quarters.
Weak exports and sluggish consumer spending contributed to the downturn.
A revision of earlier growth figures confirmed the recession, with GDP contracting 0.5% on an annualized basis.
Despite this, government officials remain optimistic about a recovery later in the year, citing strong corporate profits and rising capital spending.
Japan's economy grew 2.6% in 2004 and is forecast to expand by 2.1% in 2005, but its recovery depends on consumer spending, a weaker yen, and global economic improvements.
Analysts acknowledge the disappointing figures but caution against excessive pessimism.
